example.codeHighlighted: a:has(> img) { border: 2px solid grey; }

webFeature.description_html: The :has() CSS functional pseudo-class matches an element if any of the selectors passed as parameters would match at least one element.
webFeature.name: :has()

example.codeHighlighted: @container (min-width: 700px) { .card { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 2fr 1fr; } }

webFeature.description_html: Container size queries with the @container at-rule apply styles to an element based on the dimensions of its container.
webFeature.name: Container queries

webFeature.description_html: CSS nesting allows for shorter selectors, easier reading, and more modularity by nesting rules inside others.
webFeature.name: Nesting

example.codeHighlighted: .wrapper { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr; } .item { grid-row: 1 / 4; display: grid; grid-template-rows: subgrid; }

webFeature.description_html: The subgrid value for the grid-template-columns and grid-template-rows properties allows a grid item to inherit the grid definition of its parent grid container.
webFeature.name: Subgrid

webFeature.description_html: CSS grid is a two-dimensional layout system, which lays content out in rows and columns.
webFeature.name: Grid

resources.title: Smooth and simple transitions with the View Transitions API

webFeature.description_html: The @view-transition CSS rule sets whether a document opts-in to transitions between documents in a multi-page application. Both the old and new document must opt-in for a transition to be triggered.
webFeature.name: Cross-document view transitions

example.codeHighlighted: .teal { background: color-mix(in lab, white 20%, #34c9eb); }

webFeature.description_html: The color-mix() function mixes two colors in a given color space and by a given amount. Commonly, lighter or darker variations of a color are created by mixing with white or black.
webFeature.name: color-mix()

webFeature.description_html: The aspect-ratio CSS property controls the width-to-height ratio of elements. For <img> and <video> elements, the width and height attributes used together with height: auto control the aspect ratio while the image/video is loading.
webFeature.name: aspect-ratio

example.codeHighlighted: :where(header, main, footer) p:hover { color: red; cursor: pointer; }

webFeature.description_html: The :where() CSS functional pseudo-class takes a selector list as its argument, and matches any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list. It is functionally equivalent to the selectors in the list, but doesn't affect the CSS rule specificity.
webFeature.name: :where()

webFeature.description_html: The text-wrap: balance CSS declaration balances the length of each line when text is broken into multiple lines. Also known as headline balancing.
webFeature.name: text-wrap: balance

webFeature.description_html: The @layer CSS at-rule avoids specificity conflicts by providing priority levels for different groups of CSS rules, such as low-priority styles like resets, and high-priority styles like UI components.
webFeature.name: Cascade layers

entity.name: Comparison Functions
entity.description: `min()`, `max()`, `clamp()`
entity.descriptionClean: min(), max(), clamp()

webFeature.description_html: The min() and max() CSS functions return the minimum or maximum of the arguments, while clamp() clamps a value to a given range.
webFeature.name: min(), max(), and clamp()

resources.title: Tether elements to each other with CSS anchor positioning

webFeature.description_html: Anchor positioning places an element based on the position of another element. For example, you can place a tooltip next to the content it references.
webFeature.name: Anchor positioning

example.codeHighlighted: .foo { --color: #4488dd; background-color: hsl(from var(--color) h s calc(l * 1.2)) }

resources.title: Create a color theme with CSS Relative Color Syntax, CSS color-mix(), and CSS color-contrast()

webFeature.description_html: The from keyword for color functions (color(), hsl(), oklch(), etc.) creates a new color based on a given color by modifying the values of the input color. Also known as relative color syntax (RCS).
webFeature.name: Relative colors

entity.name: Discrete Properties Animations
entity.description: Animate to and from properties such as `display: none`
entity.descriptionHtml: Animate to and from properties such as display: none
entity.descriptionClean: Animate to and from properties such as display: none

example.codeHighlighted: /* IS-OPEN STATE */ dialog[open] { translate: 0 0; } /* EXIT STATE */ dialog { transition: opacity 1s, display 1s allow-discrete, overlay 1s allow-discrete; translate: 0 100vh; } /* 0. BEFORE-OPEN STATE */ @starting-style { dialog[open] { translate: 0 100vh; } }

webFeature.description_html: The transition-behavior: allow-discrete CSS declaration allows transitions for properties whose animation behavior is discrete. Such properties can't be interpolated and swap from their start value to the end value at 50%.
webFeature.name: transition-behavior

entity.name: CSS Logical Properties
entity.description: `margin-block-start`, `padding-inline-end`, `border-inline-start`…
entity.descriptionClean: margin-block-start, padding-inline-end, border-inline-start…

example.codeHighlighted: section { border-block: 8px solid blue; border-inline: 8px solid green; }

webFeature.description_html: CSS logical properties control borders, size, margin, and padding with directions and dimensions relative to the writing mode. For example, in a left to right, top to bottom writing mode, block-end refers to the bottom. Also known as flow relative.
webFeature.name: Logical properties

webFeature.description_html: The light-dark() CSS function accepts two colors and uses one depending on the current color scheme.
webFeature.name: light-dark()

entity.name: Wide Gamut Colors
entity.description: `lch()`, `lab()`, `oklch()`, `oklab()`
entity.descriptionClean: lch(), lab(), oklch(), oklab()

example.codeHighlighted: .foo { background-color: lab(29.2345% 39.3825 20.0664); background-color: lch(29.2345% 44.2 27); }

webFeature.description_html: The Oklab color space expresses colors in terms of lightness and how red/green and blue/yellow a color is, aiming to match how humans perceive colors. Oklch is a variant of Oklab with polar coordinates. These color spaces can be used with the CSS color(), oklab(), and oklch() functions.
webFeature.name: Oklab and Oklch

example.codeHighlighted: @property --property-name { syntax: "<color>"; inherits: false; initial-value: #c0ffee; }

webFeature.description_html: The CSS.registerProperty() static method and the @property CSS at-rule register custom properties for which types and behaviors can be defined.
webFeature.name: Registered custom properties

entity.name: Viewport-Relative Units
entity.description: `lvh` / `lvw` / `lvmin` / `lvmax`, `sv*`, `dv*`, etc.
entity.descriptionClean: lvh / lvw / lvmin / lvmax, sv*, dv*, etc.

resources.title: The large, small, and dynamic viewport units

webFeature.description_html: The sv*, lv*, and dv* CSS viewport units are relative to the smallest, largest, and current (dynamic) viewport size. They are used to size elements in relation to the viewport's dimensions.
webFeature.name: Small, large, and dynamic viewport units

example.codeHighlighted: #container { height: 300px; overflow-y: scroll; scroll-timeline: --squareTimeline y; position: relative; }

webFeature.description_html: The animation-timeline, scroll-timeline, and view-timeline CSS properties advance animations based on the user's scroll position.
webFeature.name: Scroll-driven animations

webFeature.description_html: The :focus-visible CSS pseudo-class selects elements that match the :focus pseudo-class and meets the browser's criteria for visually emphasizing focused elements.
webFeature.name: :focus-visible

entity.name: Scroll Snap
entity.description: `scroll-snap-type`, `scroll-snap-align`, `scroll-padding`…
entity.descriptionClean: scroll-snap-type, scroll-snap-align, scroll-padding…

example.codeHighlighted: .scroller { height: 300px; overflow-y: scroll; scroll-snap-type: y mandatory; } .scroller section { scroll-snap-align: start; }

webFeature.description_html: CSS scroll snap controls the panning and scrolling behavior within a scroll container.
webFeature.name: Scroll snap

webFeature.description_html: The text-wrap: pretty CSS declaration prioritizes better layout over speed when text is broken into multiple lines.
webFeature.name: text-wrap: pretty

example.codeHighlighted: p { display: -webkit-box; -webkit-line-clamp: 2; -webkit-box-orient: vertical; overflow: hidden; }

webFeature.description_html: The line-clamp CSS property limits the text in a block container to a certain number of lines. The prefixed -webkit-line-clamp is widely supported but only works with -webkit-box-orient: vertical in combination with display: -webkit-box or display: -webkit-inline-box.
webFeature.name: line-clamp

webFeature.description_html: Container style queries with the @container at-rule apply styles to an element based on the values of custom properties of its container.
webFeature.name: Container style queries

webFeature.description_html: The color-scheme CSS property sets which color schemes (light or dark) an element uses and may prevent automatic dark mode adjustments by the browser.
webFeature.name: color-scheme

entity.name: `animation-timeline`
entity.description: The animation-timeline CSS property specifies the timeline that is used to control the progress of a CSS animation.
entity.descriptionClean: The animation-timeline CSS property specifies the timeline that is used to control the progress of a CSS animation.

webFeature.description_html: The accent-color CSS property sets a color for checkboxes, radio buttons, and other form controls.
webFeature.name: accent-color

webFeature.description_html: The backdrop-filter CSS property applies graphical effects such as blurring or color shifting to the area behind an element.
webFeature.name: backdrop-filter

entity.name: Intrinsic Sizing
entity.description: `min-content`, `max-content`, `fit-content`
entity.descriptionClean: min-content, max-content, fit-content

webFeature.description_html: The min-content and max-content CSS keywords represent the smallest and largest intrinsic sizes of an element.
webFeature.name: min-content and max-content

webFeature.description_html: The position: sticky CSS declaration positions an element in the normal flow until it crosses a specified threshold, at which points it becomes fixed (stuck) at that position.
webFeature.name: Sticky positioning

example.codeHighlighted: @media (prefers-contrast: more) { .contrast { outline: 2px solid black; } }

webFeature.description_html: The prefers-contrast CSS media query sets styles based on whether the user prefers more or less contrast, the difference between foreground and background colors.
webFeature.name: prefers-contrast media query

example.codeHighlighted: .element { height: 0; overflow: hidden; transition: height 0.3s; } .element.open { height: calc-size(auto); }

resources.title: CSS interpolate-size property and calc-size() function

webFeature.description_html: The calc-size() CSS function computes mathematical expressions that include height and width keyword values, for example calc-size(fit-content, size / 2). Not to be confused with the calc() CSS function, which cannot use keyword values.
webFeature.name: calc-size()

webFeature.description_html: The column-fill CSS property sets the distribution of content across columns in a multi-column layout.
webFeature.name: column-fill

webFeature.description_html: The range syntax of CSS media queries allows you to use mathematical comparison operators such as <, >, <=, and >= to define a range of values for a media query. For example, (400px < width < 1000px) returns true if the viewport width is between 400px and 1000px.
webFeature.name: Media query range syntax

webFeature.description_html: The offset CSS property animates an element along a defined motion path.
webFeature.name: Motion path

example.codeHighlighted: @supports (display: table-cell) and (display: list-item) { //... }

webFeature.description_html: The @supports at-rule applies styles based on a browser's support for CSS features, such as a CSS property and value. Also known as feature queries.
webFeature.name: @supports

example.codeHighlighted: .target { translate: 50% 0; rotate: 30deg; scale: 1.2; }
section { display: flex gap: 1em 2em; }

webFeature.description_html: The conic-gradient() and repeating-conic-gradient() CSS functions create backgrounds that progress between two or more colors around a center point.
webFeature.name: Conic gradients

example.codeHighlighted: .foo { height: 200px; overflow: auto; overscroll-behavior-y: contain; }

webFeature.description_html: The overscroll-behavior CSS property disables default scrolling behaviors when the edges of a scrolling area are reached.
webFeature.name: overscroll-behavior

webFeature.description_html: The animation-timeline, scroll-timeline, and view-timeline CSS properties advance animations based on the user's scroll position.
webFeature.name: Scroll-driven animations

entity.name: `nth-child of S`
entity.description: Pre-filter a set of child elements before applying `nth-child` to it.
entity.descriptionHtml: Pre-filter a set of child elements before applying nth-child to it.
entity.descriptionClean: Pre-filter a set of child elements before applying nth-child to it.

example.codeHighlighted: :nth-child(2 of .highlight) border: 2px red solid; }

resources.title: More control over :nth-child() selections with the of S syntax

webFeature.description_html: The of syntax for the :nth-child() and :nth-last-child() CSS functional pseudo-classes match elements by the relative position of elements, counted from the first or last sibling matching a selector list.
webFeature.name: :nth-child() of <selector>

entity.name: Browser support
entity.description: Browser support, compatibility, and consistency issues.
entity.descriptionClean: Browser support, compatibility, and consistency issues.

example.codeHighlighted: @font-face { font-family: ExampleFont; src: url(/path/to/fonts/examplefont.woff) format("woff"); font-display: fallback; }

webFeature.description_html: The font-display CSS descriptor sets whether to show a substitute font or nothing while a font face loads. The property manages what's known as a flash of unstyled text or flash of invisible text.
webFeature.name: font-display

example.codeHighlighted: .box { background-image: image-set( url("small-balloons.jpg") 1x, url("large-balloons.jpg") 2x); }

webFeature.description_html: The image-set() CSS function provides a set of images at different resolutions or pixel densities, which the browser can pick from, depending on the device capabilities.
webFeature.name: image-set()

webFeature.description_html: The scrollbar-gutter CSS property reserves space for the scrollbar, preventing unwanted layout changes as the scrollbar appears and disappears.
webFeature.name: scrollbar-gutter

entity.name: Trigonometric Functions
entity.descriptionClean: sin(), cos(), tan()…

example.codeHighlighted: div { width: calc(100px * cos(45deg)); height: calc(100px * cos(45deg)); }

webFeature.description_html: The sin(), cos(), tan(), asin(), acos(), atan(), and atan2() CSS functions compute various trigonometric functions.
webFeature.name: sin(), cos(), tan(), asin(), acos(), atan(), and atan2() (CSS)

example.codeHighlighted: @font-face { font-family: "Fraunces"; src: url("fraunces.woff2") format("woff2"); font-weight: 200 700; } h2 { font-family: "Fraunces"; font-variation-settings: "wght" 375, "SOFT" 100; }

webFeature.description_html: The font-variation-settings CSS property sets an "axis of variability" on a variable font, such as weight, optical size, or a custom axis defined by the typeface designer. When possible, use other CSS font properties, such as font-weight: bold. Also known as variable fonts.
webFeature.name: font-variation-settings

entity.name: `field-sizing`
entity.description: Allows form controls such as `<textarea>` to be sized based on their content.
entity.descriptionHtml: Allows form controls such as <textarea> to be sized based on their content.
entity.descriptionClean: Allows form controls such as <textarea> to be sized based on their content.

example.codeHighlighted: input, textarea { field-sizing: content; min-width: 50px; max-width: 350px; }

webFeature.description_html: The field-sizing CSS property allows form controls such as <textarea> to be sized based on their content.
webFeature.name: field-sizing

entity.name: `display: contents`

entity.descriptionClean: Sets an element to display only its contents, not itself.

	</form>
</dialog>

entity.name: `@function`
entity.description: The `@function` CSS at-rule defines a custom function that takes CSS values or custom properties as arguments, and returns a CSS value.
entity.descriptionHtml: The @function CSS at-rule defines a custom function that takes CSS values or custom properties as arguments, and returns a CSS value.
entity.descriptionClean: The @function CSS at-rule defines a custom function that takes CSS values or custom properties as arguments, and returns a CSS value.

resources.title: CSS Custom Functions are coming … and they are going to be a game changer!

webFeature.description_html: The @function CSS at-rule defines a custom function that takes CSS values or custom properties as arguments, and returns a CSS value. It can be based on conditional logic such as by using the @media at-rule.
webFeature.name: @function

resources.title: CSS interpolate-size property and calc-size() function

webFeature.description_html: The scrollbar-gutter CSS property reserves space for the scrollbar, preventing unwanted layout changes as the scrollbar appears and disappears.
webFeature.name: scrollbar-gutter

example.codeHighlighted: #container { height: 300px; overflow-y: scroll; scroll-timeline: --squareTimeline y; position: relative; }

webFeature.description_html: The animation-timeline, scroll-timeline, and view-timeline CSS properties advance animations based on the user's scroll position.
webFeature.name: Scroll-driven animations

example.codeHighlighted: :root { --bounce-easing: linear( 0, 0.063, 0.25 18.2%, 1 36.4%, 0.813, 0.75, 0.813, 1, 0.938, 1, 1 ); }

webFeature.description_html: The linear() easing function for animations and transitions interpolates linearly between the control points, and can be used to approximate complex easing functions, such as a bounce effect.
webFeature.name: linear() easing

entity.name: Browser support
entity.description: Browser support, compatibility, and consistency issues.
entity.descriptionClean: Browser support, compatibility, and consistency issues.

entity.name: `field-sizing`
entity.description: Allows form controls such as `<textarea>` to be sized based on their content.
entity.descriptionHtml: Allows form controls such as <textarea> to be sized based on their content.
entity.descriptionClean: Allows form controls such as <textarea> to be sized based on their content.

example.codeHighlighted: input, textarea { field-sizing: content; min-width: 50px; max-width: 350px; }

webFeature.description_html: The field-sizing CSS property allows form controls such as <textarea> to be sized based on their content.
webFeature.name: field-sizing

entity.name: Mixins
entity.description: Group and reuse definitions dynamically.
entity.descriptionClean: Group and reuse definitions dynamically.

example.codeHighlighted: p { display: -webkit-box; -webkit-line-clamp: 2; -webkit-box-orient: vertical; overflow: hidden; }

webFeature.description_html: The line-clamp CSS property limits the text in a block container to a certain number of lines. The prefixed -webkit-line-clamp is widely supported but only works with -webkit-box-orient: vertical in combination with display: -webkit-box or display: -webkit-inline-box.
webFeature.name: line-clamp

webFeature.description_html: The accent-color CSS property sets a color for checkboxes, radio buttons, and other form controls.
webFeature.name: accent-color

webFeature.description_html: The prefers-reduced-motion CSS media query sets styles based on whether the user prefers to minimize the amount of non-essential animations on the device, such as scrolling, panning, zooming, and strobing.
webFeature.name: prefers-reduced-motion media query

webFeature.description_html: The :focus-visible CSS pseudo-class selects elements that match the :focus pseudo-class and meets the browser's criteria for visually emphasizing focused elements.
webFeature.name: :focus-visible

webFeature.description_html: The contrast-color() CSS function picks a color that has guaranteed contrast against a specified foreground or background color.
webFeature.name: contrast-color()

webFeature.description_html: The conic-gradient() and repeating-conic-gradient() CSS functions create backgrounds that progress between two or more colors around a center point.
webFeature.name: Conic gradients

webFeature.description_html: The scroll-behavior CSS property controls whether scrolling is smooth or snaps, for scroll actions not performed by the user such as those triggered by navigation.
webFeature.name: scroll-behavior

webFeature.description_html: The offset CSS property animates an element along a defined motion path.
webFeature.name: Motion path

example.codeHighlighted: .carousel { &::scroll-button(left) { content: "⬅" / "Scroll Left"; } &::scroll-button(right) { content: "⮕" / "Scroll Right"; } &::scroll-button(*):focus-visible { outline-offset: 5px; } }

webFeature.description_html: A scroll container can be navigated by activating ::scroll-marker pseudo-elements which appear in a generated ::scroll-marker-group pseudo-element, either before or after the scroll container.
webFeature.name: Scroll markers

webFeature.description_html: The color-scheme CSS property sets which color schemes (light or dark) an element uses and may prevent automatic dark mode adjustments by the browser.
webFeature.name: color-scheme

webFeature.description_html: The color() function picks a color from a given color space. Wide gamut color spaces like display-p3 allow showing more vibrant and saturated colors than the standard srgb color space.
webFeature.name: color()

example.codeHighlighted: @supports (display: table-cell) and (display: list-item) { //... }

webFeature.description_html: The @supports at-rule applies styles based on a browser's support for CSS features, such as a CSS property and value. Also known as feature queries.
webFeature.name: @supports

resources.title: Tree Counting Functions: the sibling-count() and sibling-index() notations

webFeature.description_html: The sibling-count() and sibling-index() CSS functions return integers that are useful to style elements based on their positions among siblings or on the number of siblings, for example as part of a calc() expression.
webFeature.name: sibling-count() and sibling-index()

entity.name: `<details name>` (Exclusive Accordion)
entity.description: Group `<details>` elements so that only up to one in the group can be open at a time.
entity.descriptionHtml: Group <details> elements so that only up to one in the group can be open at a time.
entity.descriptionClean: Group <details> elements so that only up to one in the group can be open at a time.

example.code:
<details open name="sidebar_panel">
	<summary>Main info</summary>
	<!-- controls -->
</details>
<details name="sidebar_panel">
	<summary>Style</summary>
	<!-- controls -->
</details>
example.codeHighlighted: <details open name="sidebar_panel"> <summary>Main info</summary> <!-- controls --> </details> <details name="sidebar_panel"> <summary>Style</summary> <!-- controls --> </details>

resources.title: Add name attribute for grouping details elements into an exclusive accordion by dbaron · Pull Request #9400 · whatwg/html · GitHub
Exclusive accordion (<details name="">) · Issue #866 · w3ctag/design-reviews · GitHub

webFeature.description_html: Multiple <details> elements which use the same name attribute are mutually exclusive. When one member of the group is opened, all other members are closed.
webFeature.name: Mutually exclusive <details> elements

example.codeHighlighted: section { display: flex gap: 1em 2em; }

entity.name: Advanced `attr()`
entity.description: Support for properties other than content
entity.descriptionClean: Support for properties other than content

resources.title: First Look at The Modern attr()

webFeature.description_html: The attr() CSS function, in the context of any property, returns the value of an attribute of an HTML element, with the option to return it as a specific type or unit. You can set a default value for missing or invalid attributes.
webFeature.name: attr()

webFeature.description_html: The animation-timeline, scroll-timeline, and view-timeline CSS properties advance animations based on the user's scroll position.
webFeature.name: Scroll-driven animations

webFeature.description_html: The column-fill CSS property sets the distribution of content across columns in a multi-column layout.
webFeature.name: column-fill

webFeature.description_html: The backdrop-filter CSS property applies graphical effects such as blurring or color shifting to the area behind an element.
webFeature.name: backdrop-filter

example.codeHighlighted: @font-face { font-family: "Fraunces"; src: url("fraunces.woff2") format("woff2"); font-weight: 200 700; } h2 { font-family: "Fraunces"; font-variation-settings: "wght" 375, "SOFT" 100; }

webFeature.description_html: The font-variation-settings CSS property sets an "axis of variability" on a variable font, such as weight, optical size, or a custom axis defined by the typeface designer. When possible, use other CSS font properties, such as font-weight: bold. Also known as variable fonts.
webFeature.name: font-variation-settings

entity.name: `animation-timeline`
entity.description: The animation-timeline CSS property specifies the timeline that is used to control the progress of a CSS animation.
entity.descriptionClean: The animation-timeline CSS property specifies the timeline that is used to control the progress of a CSS animation.

entity.name: Viewport-Relative Units
entity.description: `lvh` / `lvw` / `lvmin` / `lvmax`, `sv*`, `dv*`, etc.
entity.descriptionClean: lvh / lvw / lvmin / lvmax, sv*, dv*, etc.

resources.title: The large, small, and dynamic viewport units

webFeature.description_html: The sv*, lv*, and dv* CSS viewport units are relative to the smallest, largest, and current (dynamic) viewport size. They are used to size elements in relation to the viewport's dimensions.
webFeature.name: Small, large, and dynamic viewport units

resources.title: Tree Counting Functions: the sibling-count() and sibling-index() notations

webFeature.description_html: The sibling-count() and sibling-index() CSS functions return integers that are useful to style elements based on their positions among siblings or on the number of siblings, for example as part of a calc() expression.
webFeature.name: sibling-count() and sibling-index()
